clusters.title: Revisiting Jill of the Jungle, the last game Tim Sweeney designed
clusters.neutral_headline: Revisiting Jill of the Jungle, Tim Sweeney's Last Game

items.title: Revisiting Jill of the Jungle, the last game Tim Sweeney designed
items.standfirst: DOS platformers didn't have a reputation for being fun, but this one is a blast.
items.content: Boy, was 1992 a different time for computer games. Epic MegaGames’ Jill of the Jungle illustrates that as well as any other title from the era. Designed and programmed by Epic Games CEO Tim Sweeney, the game was meant to prove that console-style games of the original Nintendo era could work just as well on PCs. (Later, the onus of proof would often be in the reverse direction.) Also, it had a female protagonist, which Sweeney saw as a notable differentiator at the time. That’s pretty wild to think about in an era of Tomb Raider‘s Lara Croft, Horizon Forbidden West‘s Aloy, Life is Strange‘s Max Caulfield, Returnal‘s Selene Vassos, Control‘s Jesse Faden, The Last of Us‘ Ellie Williams, and a seemingly endless list of others—to say nothing of the fact that many players of all genders who played the games Mass Effect and Cyberpunk 2077 seem to agree that the female protagonist options in those are more compelling than their male alternatives. As wacky as it is to remember that the idea of a female character was seen as exceptional at any point (and with the acknowledgement that this game was nonetheless not the first to do that), it’s still neat to see how forward-thinking Sweeney was in many respects—and not just in terms of cultural norms in gaming.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: Ars Technica reviewed Jill of the Jungle, a DOS platformer.
The game was designed by Tim Sweeney.
The review notes the game is surprisingly enjoyable.
DOS platformers were not known for being fun.
The game is considered a blast from the past.

clusters.title: Achieving lasting remission for HIV
clusters.neutral_headline: Promising Trials for HIV Remission Using Antibodies

items.title: Achieving lasting remission for HIV
items.standfirst: Promising trials using engineered antibodies suggest that "functional cures" may be in reach.
items.content: Around the world, some 40 million people are living with HIV. And though progress in treatment means the infection isn’t the death sentence it once was, researchers have never been able to bring about a cure. Instead, HIV-positive people must take a cocktail of antiretroviral drugs for the rest of their lives. But in 2025, researchers reported a breakthrough that suggests that a “functional” cure for HIV—a way to keep HIV under control long-term without constant treatment—may indeed be possible. In two independent trials using infusions of engineered antibodies, some participants remained healthy without taking antiretrovirals, long after the interventions ended. In one of the trials—the FRESH trial, led by virologist Thumbi Ndung’u of the University of KwaZulu-Natal and the Africa Health Research Institute in South Africa—four of 20 participants maintained undetectable levels of HIV for a median of 1.5 years without taking antiretrovirals. In the other, the RIO trial set in the United Kingdom and Denmark and led by Sarah Fidler, a clinical doctor and HIV research expert at Imperial College London, six of 34 HIV-positive participants have maintained viral control for at least two years.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: Trials using engineered antibodies show promise.
The trials aim for "functional cures" for HIV.
The antibodies are designed to fight HIV.
The research suggests lasting remission is possible.
The article was published by Ars Technica.
